Here are some tips to keep you and your loved ones safe:  *When the rains come, look for weather updates and emergency instructions on local radio and TV. *Know where to go and how to reach higher ground. *Build or restock your emergency preparedness kit to include sandbags, flashlights, batteries, cash and first aid supplies, important papers, medical and pet supplies. *Don't drive in flood water! If you haven't already, now's a great time to make sure you're stocked with flashlights, batteries, candles, sandbags, first aid and medical supplies, potable water, foods that require no preparation, pet supplies, etc. Fully charge your cell phones tonight. You should be prepared for flash flooding, power outages, downed trees, disabled cars in the road, and dangerous wind gusts. Especially if traveling in more remote or colder areas, bring blankets and water. It'll also be a good idea to stay tuned to local TV or radio stations for emergency announcements. It's better to be prepared for a false alarm than caught off guard during a serious emergency.

Each February, we commemorate Black History Month—our annual opportunity to celebrate the rich cultural, political and economic legacy of the African-American community and honor the leaders and activists who too often gave their last full measure of devotion in pursuit of racial equality.  This year, it is not simply enough to praise the names of now-beloved icons like Martin Luther King, Jr., Harriet Tubman and Frederick Douglass. It is instead important to consider how these figures were vilified in their own time so we do not repeat the same mistakes. It is not enough to read about the dream of which Doctor King so eloquently spoke; instead, we must remember that we are still very far from his promised land.  We live in an era where voting rights are under attack—where a state in this nation deliberately restricted voting hours to affect the African-American community, and admitted so in court. Black Americans still face rampant inequality and discrimination in housing, employment, education, and criminal justice. If we are truly to achieve equality, we must strive to correct these injustices.  I believe it is possible, but we have work to do.  As Tubman said, every great dream begins with a dreamer. But any dream is only as strong as the strength of those who fight for it. I want to take this opportunity to thank my colleagues in Congress and my friends in communities across America for their continued struggle to achieve justice. Power concedes nothing without a demand, and those demands are as needed now as they ever were.

I have received a number of inquiries from worried residents about the situation with the Oroville Dam spillway. I am monitoring the latest developments, especially with another storm hitting today and tomorrow.  Despite the damage, there is no imminent danger to the dam itself, and water levels are being actively managed by the Department of Water Resources through timed releases. As expected, the overnight flow rate of 20,000 cubic feet per second caused additional erosion to the spillway. Engineers are on site to actively monitor the integrity of the structure. Everything is occurring as DWS expected it to, and there are currently no threats to public safety.   In case the amount of water arriving in the upcoming storm is too much to handle through these releases, DWR has a contingency plan to use an emergency spillway. Currently, the water level at Lake Oroville is about 30 feet below an unlined emergency spillway that would dump water onto unpopulated land. While this could pose problems downstream because of debris, water managers in the Feather River watershed are actively working together to create room to capture runoff in case this becomes necessary.  DWR has been clearing debris, including rocks and trees, from the hillside where the emergency spillway would flow, just in case it becomes necessary. They are also making every effort to protect fish from any harmful effects, and have been evacuating them to the Thermalito Annex.  To access the latest news about lake conditions, inflows, and outflows, call 530-534-2307 for a recorded message that will be frequently updated with the latest information.

The draconian budget proposal unveiled yesterday by the Trump Administration does not reflect American values. It is a cruel departure from the solid, bipartisan approach Congress took in passing the omnibus bill just three weeks ago—a bill that preserved funding for science, supported search for cures, and protected our nation’s most vulnerable people.  This new proposal takes this Administration’s attack on America’s most vulnerable to new heights. It includes a 20% cut to the Children’s Health Insurance Program (CHIP), which provides affordable health care to America’s poorest children. It cuts Medicaid by an additional $610 billion on top of the $880 billion included in the repeal of the Affordable Care Act. It also harms public health. This proposal would cut funding for the National Institute of Health by nearly $7 billion, severely damaging our ability to find cures to diseases like Alzheimer’s. This bill would also hurt our efforts to build a clean energy economy, gutting $1.4 billion from the Department of Energy’s Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy Program.  But even as this budget causes direct harm to the poor, the vulnerable, and the middle class, it provides massive tax giveaways to America’s wealthiest that will blow a massive hole in the deficit—a hallmark of the Trump Administration. But they simply assume the math will add up by making wildly unrealistic assumptions about economic growth. Here’s the bottom line in the real world: Under this budget, Trump’s billionaire friends win, and the American people lose.

This is what I feared. California’s seniors aren’t getting a fair Cost-of-Living Adjustment (COLA) in their Social Security checks. Sadly, that’s forcing many of our seniors to take out predatory high-interest “payday” loans that have a long history of trapping Americans in debt. It shouldn’t have to come to this—there’s a very easy step we can take to ensure COLAs keep up to pace with the rising living costs for our seniors. It’s a bill I introduced called the Fair COLA Act of 2017.   This bill would tie COLA calculations to a Consumer Price Index for the Elderly (CPI-E) that actually reflects how retirees spend their money—especially in healthcare and housing. Currently, the COLA calculation is based on the living standards for younger, urban wage earners who spend their money much differently than retirees. Seniors and retirees deserve to have a program that evolves along with their cost of living, and Congress can take a very simple step to make that a reality.

A recent audit found that six California school districts bought food from foreign sources without justification. The results of this audit highlight the glaring need for stronger legislation to enforce the Buy American provisions of the school lunch program. Right now, the Buy American provisions for school food programs are ill-defined guidelines that don’t have the force of law. As a consequence, they are rarely followed and violations are not enforced. Congressman LaMalfa and I have authored the American Food for American Schools Act to address these deficiencies. Our bipartisan legislation is simple: if school districts feel they need to purchase foreign-produced foods, they are required to submit a publicly available waiver explaining why. The United States has been at war in Afghanistan for 16 years. We have lost more than 2,200 servicemembers, with tens of thousands more wounded. We have spent more than $3 billion per month to continue the conflict, with little gain on the ground. This evening, the President presented yet another "new" strategy to win the longest war in U.S. history. But to what end? This critically important decision should compel Congress to exercise its constitutional responsibility to fully debate our goals and set clear guidelines for our actions. That's why I introduced H.R. 1666 with my Republican colleague, Walter Jones, which would prohibit funds to be used for most military operations in Afghanistan unless Congress debates and passes a clear Authorization for the Use of Military Force (AUMF).

I know I speak for every American when I say we are praying for the crew of the U.S.S. John McCain and their families as search and rescue efforts continue for the ten missing sailors. As a Member of the Seapower Subcommittee of the House Armed Services Committee, I will work with my colleagues to ensure that review is thorough and that resources are available to prevent similar tragedies in the future. The temporary operational pause implemented by the U.S. Navy today is an appropriate first step.

This week, Walter Jones and I spoke with Newsweek about President Trump's strategy in Afghanistan, as well as our bipartisan bill that would require Congress to debate and vote on a new Authorization to Use Military Force (AUMF) if it wants to continue our nation's conflicts abroad.   The Bush, Obama, and Trump Administrations have all used the incredibly broad 2001 AUMF, which was designed for the Afghanistan war, as the basis for military actions across three different regions. I sat down with KPIX CBS San Francisco Bay Area last week to discuss the federal relief efforts in response to the California wildfires.   FEMA has a strong track record of providing emergency services and relief in disaster situations. But their record of maintaining those resources and support over the long term is often mired with issues. The State of California alone is still owed over $4 billion in funding that the federal government has promised to commit to help the state respond to natural disasters. Some of these IOU’s date back almost 20 years.   This issue of long-term disaster relief funding is created by the way Congress manages FEMA’s spending. Under the current funding structure, once the Disaster Relief Fund that FEMA utilizes to provide disaster relief is diminished, FEMA can only afford to provide relief to immediate disasters. Congress must fund the Disaster Relief Fund at an adequate level now to ensure FEMA has the resources it needs to provide relief to communities that have been devastated by a natural disaster from day one and beyond.

The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office (CBO) issued the first official cost estimate for modernizing the U.S. nuclear triad over the next 30 years.   The report confirmed what we have known for years--rebuilding the U.S. nuclear triad is a costly endeavor that the American taxpayers ultimately bear responsibility for. No one seems to have an answer as to which federal programs, many of which are critical for ensuring national security, will need to be cut to pay for this massive project. Now that we have our first official cost estimate from the CBO, I hope we will rethink this critically important decision and consider spending these funds in a more productive manner for the American people.

Today, along with Rep. Doug LaMalfa, I introduced an amendment that requires additional safety reviews for the Oroville Dam. The last environmental review of the dam was completed over a decade ago, and no new review has been conducted since the spillway suffered significant structural damage earlier this year.   Before the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) re-licenses the Oroville Dam for 50 years, we must consider the most accurate and up-to-date information regarding public safety and environmental concerns. Rep. LaMalfa and I hope to make that possible with our amendment.

The federal government is preparing to re-license the Oroville Dam for another 50 years--which requires an environmental review. However, the last environmental review of the dam was completed over a decade ago.    After the incidents that occurred at the Oroville Dam earlier this year, I believe we owe it to our local communities to ensure the long-term safety and integrity of the dam before we re-licence it. Rep. Doug LaMalfa and I have introduced a bipartisan amendment that would require the federal government to perform an updated environmental review of the Oroville Dam.   Unfortunately, House leadership rejected the amendment late last night. But that won't stop my resolve to ensure the safety and well-being of the communities surrounding the Oroville Dam.
